documents.document: @TMariner72 @DIfferent_Name2 What colour did you go for? I've done all our fences etc. in a dark blue/grey. Looks amazing with greenery :-)

@DIfferent_Name2 Best thing might be laying an entire concrete slab and go for one that has a sloping roof from front to back rather than an apex - less potential for repairs and damage and more room inside, too. We did that in last house, worked well :-)

@DIfferent_Name2 Not an expert but it’s wood from me; good choice environmentally, easy to paint and maintain for decades if it’s put on a proper base and you can get some really pretty ones too that fair lift a garden. :-)

@MacJude It has rather changed my view on a few things. You feel like part burglar, part detective going through the things, rubber gloves, breathing masks on... then you come across something steeped in personal memories and wow - brain zooms in and out, processing.
@jenninscotland It’s shocking. Have had my eyes thoroughly opened re smoke damage too. Incredible :-( Be cosy sweets. X
@brianjlawlor Exactly that, Brian. And they’re safely installed in a lovely temporary place now too. Relief & gratitude all round. :’-)

Today has been harrowing but also filled with love and care. A trio of us completed inventory of everything damaged in fire at my Aunty & Uncles’. (Everyone’s fine, thankfully). 🖤 Don’t use electric blankets, folks. Life is too precious. https://t.co/Jn52i9DGgy

Loved catching up with the two most recent @TheSnashPodcast's today. @GlasgowPam & her Mum's advocacy, intuition and activism for disability equality is so inspiring, instructive and affirming. And Lydia Morrow's stories & voice hook you from the get-go. Well done, Jennie. 🖤

Love the idea (first learned via Liz Gilbert’s Magic Lessons podcasts) that stories and poems move thru the air and you catch them if & when you can. Just caught 400 words of something special in a forest. Thankful for the Notes app and a dog who appreciates pauses. 🖤

Changing my ending to emphasise the point re kids & curriculum; when we normalise playground behaviours that victimise people, i.e., ‘kids, huh!’, we facilitate the behaviours’ transition to adulthood via conditioning, extrapolating out then and into ALL relationships.

We need to add awareness about Gaslighting to the curriculum too, IMO. Kids often use it as a playground tactic in cliques - it’s such an accessible, self-presenting power-play, so it’s really important we learn how to identify, neutralise & replace it with honest communication.

On a micro (‘toxic’ friend, colleague, family member etc.) and macro (Farage, Trump, ISIS, Hitler) basis, this is the semi-sophisticated, triple-bluff art of gaslighting; weaponising disadvantage to protect a goal the perpetrator knows to be flawed.

Farage will simply exploit the lack of knowledge, filling the gap with unscrutinised fiction, waving the monarchy around, plus an occasional Morris dancer and a steak & kidney pie as ‘evidence’ of a ‘successful’ nation and, with the help of sensationalist media bias, job done.

This lie will get huge traction because UK curriculum at primary & secondary levels fails spectacularly on including content & discussion on our modern politics and impact on other countries. We could learn & adapt so much from Germany here, to our HUGE benefit.

Gaslighters are particularly good at calling other people/issues by names that apply much more fittingly to themselves. Gaslighting most effective when the perpetrator gets opportunity to tell their lie repeatedly in airspace they control. Repetition of the lie is absolutely key. https://t.co/nobjEhdktc

@CarolMFarrelly @GoldenHareBooks @VagabondVoices I finished TKM on a perfect secret beach nr Glenuig, sitting on a rock, looking over to Eigg on a scorching summers' day. Only a place as lovely could've softened the grief blow of closing that book! Loving responses to Helen's work. So incredibly comforting. X

@CarolMFarrelly @GoldenHareBooks @VagabondVoices It's a great book group choice, Carol. A potential classic, have heard it compared to To Kill A Mockingbird several times now. It really hits bone and heart.

Apropos of me smiling & unloading a crate, Tesco delivery man wants everyone to understand Brexit will be fine and to stop freaking out. ‘As long as you have your health - that’s what matters.’ And in a ‘farewell NHS, hello more food banks’ kinda way, he’s absolutely right.
